channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: At Least 10 Killed as Israel Begins Major Military Operation in West Bank
item.description: Hundreds of troops entered cities in the occupied territory, targeting Palestinian militants. It was a significant escalation after months of raids that have unfolded alongside the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: With Hezbollah-Israel Conflict Contained, Iran’s Next Move May Be Modest
item.description: After weeks of regional fears about a broader war, Hezbollah’s limited attack on Israel suggests that Iran, like its ally, wants to hem in the risk of escalation.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah fighters carrying the coffin of Fuad Shukr, a senior commander who was killed in an Israeli airstrike on July 30.

item.title: Last Crusade of Mexico’s President: A Drastic Redesign of the Judiciary
item.description: A showdown over plans to reshape the entire judiciary is raising fears over the effect on the rule of law in Mexico and trade with the United States.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Paulina Villegas
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador, who has enjoyed historically high approval ratings, surrounded by a crowd of supporters during a rally in 2022 in Mexico City.

item.title: For Russia, Repelling Incursion Matters Less Than Advancing in Donbas
item.description: Despite its overwhelming firepower, Russia has been unable for weeks to push Ukrainian troops back across the border, with the failure as much the result of priorities as a lack of personnel.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman about to board an evacuation train in Pokrovsk, Ukraine, on Tuesday. The advance on the city by Russian forces has not been slowed by the Kursk incursion.

item.title: Germany’s State Elections Are Likely to Reveal a Still-Divided Country
item.description: Closely watched elections in the former East Germany are likely to reveal a still-divided country and yield a worrying challenge to Berlin.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: The city center of Erfurt, in the German state of Thuringia. It is one of three states in the former East Germany facing critical elections in September.

item.title: In Quebec’s Casse-Croûtes, Fast Food for a Short but Sweet Summer
item.description: By now, the most famous product of Quebec’s casse-croûtes, the poutine, has gone international. But can the guédille or the pinso ever become just as popular?
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Nasuna Stuart-Ulin
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Customers consulting the extensive menu as they wait in line to order a nighttime treat from Casse-Croûte La Mollière in Cap-des-Rosiers, Gaspé, Quebec.

item.title: Shelling Kills 6 in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: The rest of the country, though, was largely spared from another consecutive night of large-scale Russian bombardment.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kryvyi Rih, Ukraine, on Wednesday after a strike earlier this week.

item.title: ‘No Barrier’ to Nuclear Talks With U.S., Iran’s Supreme Leader Says
item.description: It was unclear if Ayatollah Ali Khamenei’s comments signaled any shift in Iran’s stance, but the country’s new president has called for an accord that would relieve Western sanctions against it.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei hinted on Tuesday that Iran may be open to pursuing nuclear negotiations with the United States.

item.title: Who Is Telegram’s Pavel Durov and Why Was He Arrested in France?
item.description: Pavel Durov has been detained in France, as part of wide-ranging investigation into criminal activities on the messaging platform he runs.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Pavel Durov, Telegram’s founder, in 2014. He has not been charged but is currently in custody and being questioned at France’s National Anti-Fraud Office, a law enforcement agency that handles a wide range of financial crimes.

item.title: In Brazil, Wildfires Roar Across the Pantanal as Rare Wildlife Dies
item.description: In Brazil, wildfires have roared across the Pantanal, a maze of rivers, forests and marshlands that sprawl over an area 20 times the size of the Everglades.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:description: A fire in June near Corumbá, Brazil, a gateway to the Pantanal wetlands.

item.title: In Eastern Ukraine, Terrifying Bombardment and Near Total Destruction
item.description: Powerful guided “glide bombs” have helped Russia raze entire towns with ever greater speed. “When you drive into a ruined town, it’s like hopelessness,” one soldier said.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks
item.media:description: As Russia makes steady gains in the eastern region of Donetsk, Ukrainian forces face withering bombardment in the former mining town of Toretsk.

item.title: Hostage Rescued in Gaza as Israeli Airstrikes Kill Scores of Palestinians
item.description: A Bedouin Arab citizen of Israel was rescued after Israeli commandos found him alone in an underground warren, apparently abandoned by his captors.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Patrick Kingsley, Aaron Boxerman and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: The brother of freed hostage Farhan al-Qadi shows a photograph of the pair celebrating at a medical center in southern Israel on Tuesday.

item.title: Mexico Pauses Relations With U.S. Embassy Amid Clash Over Judicial Overhaul
item.description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s proposed changes to the judiciary are at the center of a diplomatic fight with the United States in the last weeks of his presidency.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico said on Tuesday that his government was pausing its relations with the U.S. Embassy.

item.title: Prosecutor to Politician: Can Kamala Harris Follow Keir Starmer’s Path to Power?
item.description: Like Kamala Harris, Prime Minister Keir Starmer was a prosecutor before embracing politics. The two share a few other traits.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris presented herself at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago last week as an unyielding protector of the rule of law.

item.title: Major Israeli-Palestinian Clashes in the West Bank: A Timeline
item.description: Israel has ramped up a crackdown in the Israeli-occupied territory since before the Israel-Hamas war began last Oct. 7. Here are some of the major raids.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Surveying damage after an Israeli military raid in the West Bank city of Jenin in November.

item.title: Jenin, a Target of Israeli Raids, Is a Symbol of Rebellion for Palestinians
item.description: For decades, Jenin has played a role as a center of opposition to occupying powers.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: A woman raised a Palestinian flag in the ruins of Jenin in 2002, after much of the area was destroyed in a two-week Israeli military offensive.

item.title: Nearly 1 Million People Are Evacuated as Typhoon Shanshan Lashes Japan
item.description: The authorities issued rare emergency warnings and said the storm could produce a large-scale disaster as it approached the mainland. Toyota closed all its factories on Wednesday afternoon.
item.dc:creator: Hisako Ueno and Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Hidetaka Komukai/Kyodo News, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Waves hitting a coastal area of western Japan on Tuesday.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Jack Smith, the special counsel.

item.title: Africa’s Debt Crisis Has ‘Catastrophic Implications’ for the World
item.description: Crushing obligations to foreign creditors that have few precedents have sapped numerous African nations of growth and stoked social instability.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Brian Otieno for The New York Times
item.media:description: Proposed tax increases resulted in deadly protests in Kenya this summer.

item.title: Can Tech Executives Be Held Responsible for What Happens on Their Platforms?
item.description: The arrest of Pavel Durov, Telegram’s founder, as part of an investigation into illicit activities on the messaging app set off worries about the personal liability of tech executives.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Cecilia Kang
item.media:description: Regulators and lawmakers are increasingly considering when to hold tech leaders directly responsible for the activities on their services, a shift punctuated by the arrest of Telegram’s founder, Pavel Durov.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: A Look at Harris’s Polling Lead
item.description: Plus, looking for love in Shanghai.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta and Justin Porter

item.title: At an Israeli Hospital, Rescued Hostage Tells of His Ordeal
item.description: Farhan al-Qadi, who was recovering in a medical center in southern Israel, told relatives and friends he had spent much of his captivity in darkness.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Friends and relatives of Farhan al-Qadi celebrated his freedom with kenafeh, a traditional Palestinian dessert, at the Soroka Medical Center in Beersheba, Israel, on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump Campaign Stokes China Fears to Lure Michigan Voters
item.description: JD Vance, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, waded into a fight over plans by Gotion, a Chinese battery plant, to build a factory in Michigan.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: JD Vance, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, speaking at a horse farm in the area of rural Michigan that has been divided over plans for a $2.4 billion factory.

item.title: Hostage’s Rescue Shines a Spotlight on Israel’s Bedouins
item.description: The Bedouins of the Negev desert suffered painful losses on Oct. 7, but less attention has been focused on their plight than on some of the other victims of the Hamas-led attack.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Bedouin minority in the Negev desert in 2021.

item.title: Off Spain’s Coast, Orcas Ram a Sailboat
item.description: A pod of orcas damaged a boat and left its two-person crew stranded. It was the latest in a string of attacks that research suggests could be used for hunting practice.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Orcas damaged a sailboat’s rudder prompting the Spanish Coast Guard to tow the boat ashore, off the coast of Galicia, Spain, on Sunday.

item.title: Harris and Trump Embrace Tariffs
item.description: Both Democrats and Republicans are expressing support for tariffs to protect American industry, reversing decades of trade thinking in Washington.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Roger Kisby for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump’s proposals include a 10 to 20 percent tariff on most imports, as well as a more than 60 percent tariff on Chinese products.

item.title: What Across-the-Board Tariffs Could Mean for the Global Economy
item.description: Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, has floated the idea of a 10 percent tariff on all U.S. imports, a plan that economists say could badly damage trade.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Adam Amengual for The New York Times
item.media:description: A universal tariff has the potential to deliver a devastating jolt to world trade, economists have warned.

item.title: The Crypto Industry Loudly Defends Telegram’s Pavel Durov
item.description: When the messaging app’s founder, Pavel Durov, was arrested, he received a flood of support from a multitrillion-dollar industry that relies on it.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:description: Pavel Durov, center, the founder of Telegram, at a cryptocurrency conference in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, in April.

item.title: Israeli Minister Ben-Gvir Draws Anger for Comments on Disputed Holy Site
item.description: In the latest in a series of provocations, Itamar Ben-Gvir agreed that a new synagogue should be built at the site, which Jews call the Temple Mount and Muslims know as the Aqsa Mosque complex.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg, Gabby Sobelman and Rawan Sheikh Ahmad
item.media:credit: Afif Amireh for The New York Times
item.media:description: The site, known as the Al Aqsa Mosque compound to Muslims and the Temple Mount to Jews, is one of the holiest in both religions.

item.title: Solingen, Germany, Becomes Reluctant Symbol of Migration Battles
item.description: After the fatal stabbing, which prosecutors say was committed by a Syrian who was rejected for asylum, the city of Solingen finds itself at the center of a longstanding debate over migrants.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: A makeshift memorial for the victims of the Solingen knife attack in Germany included flowers, candles and a card bearing the inscription “Love instead of hate.”

item.title: Who is Farhan al-Qadi, the Israeli Hostage Found in Gaza?
item.description: Mr. al-Qadi, a member of Israel’s Bedouin minority, was working as an unarmed guard at a kibbutz near the Gaza border when he was abducted, a member of his family said. His family was overjoyed at his return.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Israeli security outside the Soroka Medical Center in Beersheba, southern Israel, where Farhan al-Qadi met his family and friends.

item.title: Israel’s Hostage Rescues During the War in Gaza: What to Know
item.description: Israeli forces have freed eight hostages in military operations in Gaza since Oct. 7, out of the approximately 250 abducted in the Hamas-led attacks.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Former hostage Andrey Kozlov, center, arriving at Sheba Medical Center near Tel Aviv in June, after being rescued from Gaza.

item.title: After Israel-Hezbollah Clashes, Dread Lingers in the Middle East
item.description: For people across the region, any relief that the adversaries had stepped back from an all-out war mixed with fears that the conflicts in Gaza and Lebanon remained unresolved.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Hwaida Saad
item.media:description: A family leaving their home in the Lebanese village of Khiam, near the southern border with Israel, on Monday.

item.title: Top Biden Aide Visits China to Reinforce U.S. Strategy
item.description: The national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, will raise thorny issues like Taiwan and Russia with only months left before a new administration takes office.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Ng Han Guan
item.media:description: Jake Sullivan, second from right, arriving in Beijing on Tuesday.

item.title: Israel launches a deadly airstrike in the West Bank, and other news.
Russia Bombards Ukraine, Killing at Least 2
item.description: The bombardment that began on Monday could have additional significance, coming three weeks after the Ukrainian military’s incursion into Russia’s Kursk region.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: The scene of a Russian missile strike in Kryvyi Rih, Ukraine, on Tuesday. A missile attack on a hotel in the city killed two people.

item.title: Typhoon Shanshan Approaches Japan, Bringing Heavy Rain and Winds
item.description: Japan’s southern islands were forecast to receive the most rain. The powerful storm has forced flight cancellations and disrupted high-speed rail travel.
item.dc:creator: Hisako Ueno and Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Hidetaka Komukai/Kyodo News, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Waves hitting a coastal area of western Japan on Tuesday, as Typhoon Shanshan approached.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The attacks hit across a wide swath of Ukraine.

item.title: A Mercedes-Benz Fire Jolts South Korea’s E.V. Transition
item.description: The government is aggressively promoting electric cars. But a dramatic blaze in an underground lot has left some potential buyers worried about safety.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: Government officials and Mercedes-Benz employees examined the electric sedan that caught fire in Incheon, South Korea, this month. Hundreds of nearby vehicles were damaged.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Russia Launches a Large-Scale Attack
item.description: Plus, badminton instead of sex.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta and Justin Porter
item.media:description: A building damaged by a Russian missile strike on a village in the Zaporizhzhia region.

item.title: Dam Collapse Devastates Communities in Eastern Sudan
item.description: The Arba’at dam fell apart after days of heavy rain, killing villagers and flooding communities.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: Trucks were damaged after the deadly collapse of the Arba’at dam on Sunday.

item.title: Telegram Turmoil Threatens Chronicle of Russia’s War in Ukraine
item.description: The detention of Telegram’s founder has highlighted the messaging app’s outsize status in Europe’s deadliest war since World War II.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Pavel Durov, the founder and chief executive of Telegram, in San Francisco in 2014.

item.title: How Pavel Durov, Telegram’s Founder, Went From Russia’s Mark Zuckerberg to Wanted Man
item.description: Pavel Durov’s anti-establishment streak helped him create one of the world’s biggest online platforms, which emphasizes free speech. It also put a target on his back.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur and Adam Satariano
item.media:description: Pavel Durov, Telegram’s founder, in 2014. “Privacy, ultimately, is more important than our fear of bad things happening, like terrorism,” he posted in 2015.

item.title: Italy Opens Investigation Into Captain of Sunken Yacht’s Conduct
item.description: The investigation does not necessarily imply that formal charges will follow against the captain, James Cutfield.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:description: The Bayesian sank a week ago off the coast of Sicily, killing seven of the 22 people on board.

item.title: Hungry for Clean Energy, Facebook Looks to a New Type of Geothermal
item.description: As electricity demand from data centers soars, Meta and Google are looking at a novel solution: harnessing clean heat far below Earth’s surface.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Fervo Energy geothermal site near Milford, Utah, last year. Meta has announced a similar project with a Sage Geosystems in Texas.

item.title: At Least 38 Killed in Attacks in Southwestern Pakistan
item.description: At least 38 people have been killed in several assaults across Baluchistan Province since Sunday in what appears to be part of a campaign by armed separatists in the region.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
item.media:description: A vehicle on Monday that was said to have been set on fire by gunmen in the Pakistani province of Baluchistan.

item.title: Chinese Military Plane Breaches Japanese Airspace, a First
item.description: The territorial violation by China is the latest in a series of events amplifying tensions between Beijing and Japan.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Hisako Ueno
item.media:credit: Chen Jimin/China News Service, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A Y-9 aircraft at an airshow in Zhuhai, China, in 2022, in a photo released by Chinese state media.

item.title: Polio Vaccines Arrive in Gaza, but Distributing Them Is the Next Challenge
item.description: UNICEF is pushing for a pause in the fighting to allow health workers to get two doses to every child, after Gaza recorded its first polio case in 25 years.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: Children walking near garbage and raw sewage at a camp for displaced Palestinians in Deir al Balah in central Gaza this month.

item.title: China to Hold Live-Fire Drills Near War-Torn Myanmar’s
item.description: Beijing likely wants to signal to Myanmar’s junta leaders that they should return to peace talks and de-escalate the conflict, analysts said.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: People’s Liberation Army cadets in Qingdao, China, earlier this year.

item.title: Russia Pounds Ukraine With ‘One of the Largest Strikes’ of the War
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned an assault of more than 200 missiles and drones that ranged from Kyiv to Odesa to Ukraine’s West. Energy infrastructure was again a target.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Taking shelter in a subway station in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday. Russia struck regions across the country.

item.title: Hong Kong Defends Sex Ed Advice That Includes Playing Badminton
item.description: Top officials in the Chinese territory have defended new sex education guidance that critics call regressive. Young people are amused.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Wang and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Jeffrey Greenberg/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Playing badminton in Hong Kong.

item.title: No Evidence that Maduro Won, Says Top Venezuelan Election Official
item.description: In an interview with The New York Times, an electoral council official expressed grave doubts about claims to victory by the authoritarian president, Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:description: Juan Carlos Delpino, a member of Venezuela’s National Electoral Council, said the body “failed the country” in proclaiming President Nicolás Maduro the victor in elections last month.

item.title: Dismantling the Ship That Drilled for the Ocean’s Deepest Secrets
item.description: The JOIDES Resolution, which for decades was key to advancing the understanding of the Earth and its innards, concluded what could be its final scientific expedition.
item.dc:creator: Maya Wei-Haas
item.media:credit: Heba Khamis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the International Ocean Discovery Program welcomed the arrival of the JOIDES Resolution in Amsterdam on Aug. 2 for its final berth.

item.title: Getting to Know Kenya Through a Local Hiking Club
item.description: The author sought an authentic experience, and found it in Lets Drift, “an exuberant Kenyan-centered enterprise” of people living in and near Nairobi.
item.dc:creator: Rolf Potts

item.title: A Fire in East London Recalls Deadly Grenfell Cladding Scandal
item.description: More than 80 people were evacuated in the early hours of Monday from a building that had used similar insulation.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Smoke continued to rise on Monday from an apartment building in East London after an early morning fire broke out.

item.title: Israel Averts All-Out War With Hezbollah, but Regional Conflicts Grind On
item.description: Relief that an eruption of violence across the border between Israel and Lebanon has been contained is tempered by a lack of progress in ending the fighting in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Smoke billowing from the site of an airstrike on Zibqin in southern Lebanon on Sunday.

item.title: Gaza Cease-Fire Talks Will Continue in Cairo, Officials Say
item.description: Four days of high-level meetings failed to achieve a breakthrough, but people briefed on the talks said discussions on technical issues would take place in the coming days.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and James C. McKinley Jr.
item.media:description: Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip, on Saturday.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A building in northern Israel damaged during a Hezbollah attack.

item.title: Fox Hunters in the U.K. Want Protected Status Under Discrimination Law
item.description: A lobbying group is preparing a bid to define hunting with animals as a protected belief. Many experts have questions.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Warwickshire Hunt in February 2023, in Warwickshire, England. Since fox hunting with packs of dogs was banned in 2005, many hunts use trail hunting, where dogs follow a scent trail of fox urine instead of a live animal.

item.title: Iceland Ice Wall Collapse: 1 Tourist Is Dead and 1 Is Injured
item.description: Rescuers on Monday called off a search for what they initially believed were two other trapped tourists after it became clear that all the visitors were accounted for.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri and Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: STOD2/ Vilhelm Gunnarsson, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Rescue teams at the scene of an ice cave collapse at the Breidamerkurjokull glacier in southeastern Iceland on Monday.
